concept.title: DTD: Coding requirements for element-configuration modules
concept.shortdesc: Element-configuration modules (constraint and expansion) have specific coding requirements.

section.title: The tagname.attributes parameter entity
section.p: When the attribute set for an element is constrained or expanded, there is a declaration of the tagname.attributes parameter entity that defines the modified attributes.

The following parameter entity defines a new attribute intended for use with various table elements:
dd.codeblock: <!ENTITY % cellPurposeAtt-d-attribute-expansion "cell-purpose (sale | out-of-stock | new | last-chance | inherit | none) #IMPLIED" >

section.p: For expansion modules, note the following considerations.The tagname.attributes parameter entity can be defined in an attribute specialization module, or it can be defined directly in the expansion module.

section.title: The tagname.content parameter entity
section.p: When the content model for an element is constrained or expanded, there is a declaration of the tagname.content parameter entity that defines the modified content model.

example.p: The following list provides examples for both constraint and expansion modules:

dd.p: The following parameter entity defines a more restricted content model for topic, in which the shortdesc element is required.
Note that replacing a base element with domain extensions is a form of constraint that can be accomplished directly in the document-type shell. No constraint module is required.

In the following example, the pre base type is removed from the entity declaration, effectively allowing only specializations of pre but not pre itself.<!ENTITY % pre "%pr-d-pre; | %sw-d-pre; | %ui-d-pre;">
The redefinition of the content model references the parameter entity that was defined in the element specialization module.
